p: However, model selection showed an even stronger direct SST effect ( Table 4). Ocean temperatures play an important role in the spatial distribution of fish populations ( Beentjes et al., 2002). Warmer than usual SST is often an indication of increased stratification of the water column where a layer of warmer water sits on top of cooler water. This disrupts the benthic-pelagic coupling, i.e., mixing processes that regulate nutrient flow between benthos and surface waters ( Jones et al., 2014). Land run-off has been identified as a major source of nutrients for the South Otago continental shelf, which results in higher near-surface nutrient concentrations ( Hawke, 1989), so that vertical mixing is likely of crucial importance for benthic productivity and subsequent prey abundance in the penguinsâ€™ home ranges. Penguin foraging conditions are likely compromised under stratified, warm-water conditions.
